item.title: CoSi standalond binary release
item.description:
Dear all,

with the acceptance of the paper “Keeping Authorities ‘Honest or Bust’ with Decentralized Witness Cosigning” http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.08768 at IEEE S&P 2016 http://www.ieee-security.org/TC/SP2016/, we updated our code to make it even more easy to integrate it with your projects.

For details on how to use the CoSi-application, go to https://github.com/dedis/cosi/blob/master/README.md .

The code is now based on our latest cothority-framework and can be called from your program to generate a collective signature of a file. The same code also verifies the signature or can be used as a server if you want to run your own cothority-group.

There are two proposals to include the collective signing and verification in open-source-libraries: - Go crypto library: https://github.com/bford/golang-x-crypto - C libsodium: https://github.com/bford/libsodium Both forks can be used to verify the signatures created by our latest CoSi-release.

If you have questions or remarks, feel free to contact us here or open issues on https://github.com/dedis/cosi .

Yours, the DeDiS-team

item.title: 2016-04 master-release
item.description:
We’re working hard for bringing services to SDA, and we’re nearly there. But before we break everything by merging the services into development, we saved development by merging it into master. The list of improvement is long, but to say the least:

  • lots of bug fixes, comments and documentation
  • added a new JVSS-protocol that is much easier to use
  • BFT (Byzantine Fault Tolerance) got separated from Byzcoin

item.title: cosi binary
item.description:
We just finished our latest cothority-binary for you to try out. You can fetch the binary at

https://github.com/dedis/cothority/releases/latest

or follow the compilation instructions at

https://github.com/DeDiS/cothority

Be sure to report any successful installation of your servers to

https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/cothority

Also don’t hesitate to ask questions on that forum or open issues on github.

item.title: Overview of the project
item.description:
The DeDiS-lab at EPFL started in August 2015 with the arrival of Bryan Ford at EPFL. With a team of software-engineers, PhD-students and postdocs, we’ve been working on different projects, like:

  • Cothority - getting collective signatures from thousands of signers
  • PriFi - Privacy enhanced WLANs using MixNets
